subject: Re: [junit] Re: Changing junit.framework.Assert to instance methods
msgSnippet: ... A real valid argument for multiple failures is when the structure to test does not give sufficient information when the assertEquals fails. Typically a
messageBody:
> When I've wished for multiple failures to be recorded in my tests, my
> tests were always too big. Splitting up the tests gave me more
> satisfactory tests, and pinpointed errors.


A real valid argument for multiple failures is when the structure to
test does not give sufficient information when the assertEquals fails.
Typically a Vector. If the last 2 elements of a Vector are switched,
you may not have a lot of (or too much) information from the typical
error message.

The new patch for long strings may solve some problems.

I prefer to see the problem under the view "multiple error messages in a
failure" rather than "multiple failures with an error message".

> The advantage of having the methods be static is that you can do DbC
> and have pre-/post-condition failures reported like all other JUnit
> failures.


For DbC I still prefer the JDK1.4 assert keyword since I can compile-out
the assert code for the production code and reduce the overhead. I've
heard that JDK1.5 will introduce preprocessor commands so if #ifdef is
supported, it will be possible to use JUnit for DbC and compile-out the
DbC code if needed (for production release).

-Vladimir
